that they can pass more bills using budget reconciliation, a convoluted process that allows bills related to spending to pass with a simple 51-vote majority, rather than the 60 votes usually needed to end the opposing party’s filibuster and move legislation to a vote. That may sound like good news, since Democrats only have 51 reliable votes in the Senate, but the process cannot be used to pass many of the party’s key priorities into law.

Just last month, Democrats passed a COVID-19 relief bill that excluded a promised $15 minimum wage because the parliamentarian, Elizabeth MacDonough, said the measure wasn’t a budget item and shouldn’t be part of a reconciliation bill. Democrats could have
and kept the measure in the bill, but chose not to.
There’s little chance that Democrats will be able to pass voting rights legislation or their new union rights bill using the reconciliation process.
The truth is that Democrats must still eliminate the filibuster, since using reconciliation
will not prove to be a valid ongoing substitute
. Democrats may be able to pass spending bills using reconciliation, but they cannot govern.

• MAJORITY OF COUNTRY AT HIGH RISK OF RIGGED ELECTIONS:

from the nonpartisan group RepresentUs has concluded that 35 states are at high or extreme risk of partisan redistricting, based on who is allowed to draw up new election maps and the amount of legal protections in place. That means more than 188 million people are at risk of having their election districts rigged for political gain in the next ten years. As the report notes, “Passing the For the People Act (H.R.1/ S.1), or a similar reform bill, would all but eliminate the threat of rigged congressional maps nationwide.”
